description: From Middle English hungry, from Old English hungriġ, from Proto-West Germanic *hungrug, from Proto-Germanic *hungrugaz (“hungry”); equivalent to hunger +‎ -y. Cognate with West Frisian hongerich (“hungry”), Dutch hongerig (“hungry”), German hungrig (“hungry”), Swedish hungrig (“hungry”), Icelandic hungraður (“hungry”).

entries.meaning: Affected by hunger; having an uncomfortable feeling in your stomach because you need food.
examples: My kids go to bed hungry every night because I haven’t got much money for food.
I woke up very hungry and made some toast.
All this gardening is hungry work.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) Eager, having an avid desire (‘appetite’) for something.
examples: the students are hungry to learn

entries.meaning: Not rich or fertile; poor; barren; starved.
